issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) consistently refers to the park class as "ExcellencePark" (UML class and task names), while the repository template and reference solution use the class/file name "ExcellenceLand" (ExcellenceLand.java). Additionally, the exercise title/header uses "Excellence Land", increasing the naming inconsistency. This mismatch between the class name in the specification and the actual template/solution will confuse students about which class to implement and/or which name the tests expect.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the park class name consistent across all artifacts. Options:
- Preferred: Update the problem statement (UML diagram and tasks) to refer to the class as "ExcellenceLand" (matching the exercise title and the provided template/solution).
- Alternatively: Rename the template and solution files/classes from ExcellenceLand to ExcellencePark and update filenames accordingly. Also update any task/test names that reference ExcellencePark/ExcellenceLand to the chosen name.
Ensure the class name used in the UML, task descriptions, template files, and tests is identical so students are not confused which class to implement.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to the park class as "ExcellencePark", whereas both the template and the solution repositories use the name "ExcellenceLand" for the same conceptual entity (the amusement park class with attributes excellencyLevel, excellentEnough and rides). This mismatch forces students to map between two different class names for the same concept and may cause confusion when following the UML/tasks versus the provided starter code and reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the class name across all artifacts. The least disruptive fix is to update the problem statement (and UML/task descriptions) to use the name "ExcellenceLand" instead of "ExcellencePark" so it matches the template and solution. Alternatively, rename the template and solution class files to "ExcellencePark" if you prefer that name, but ensure all tasks, UML, template files, and tests consistently use the same identifier.
